review: We love it and we ARE NOT techno-geeks.  The only disappointing thing was that we didn't realize you have to have a preferred provider for the Watch ESPN program.  Direct TV, OF COURSE, is not on the list.  So if you are trying to get rid of Direct TV (which we are) you will have to "borrow" friend or family id from other provider (U-verse, TWC, etc.).  We have family members with U-verse who were willing to provide their info.  It's not the same as satellite quality....there are a few blips..when watching shows, but it's way worth it for us.  We were around when TV was free and we could choose what we wanted to watch.  This was our answer for affordable TV series, movies, and ESPN.  Be bold!! Cut the cable/satellite cord and go ALA carte!

review: With 22,000 reviews of the Fire TV Stick already posted, I'm coming to the party late, but better late than never, I guess. My wife and I bought the Fire TV Stick to replace an old, ailing Roku box, and we're very pleased with it. Set-up and connecting to our home wi-fi was very simple and took only a few minutes, after which the device checked for software updates, then we were ready to go. We're using the Fire TV Stick primarily for streaming Amazon Instant Video to our TV, and it works great. I installed the Fire TV app on my Kindle Fire HDX 7" tablet, and it also works very well. I especially like being able to search for movies and TV shows with voice commands from the app, which you can't do from the Fire TV remote control.I haven't used a Google Chromecast or Roku Streaming Stick, so I can't compare the Fire TV Stick to them, but so far I'm very pleased with the Amazon product, which is ideal for anyone who's heavily into the Amazon environment of instant video, music, and games.
author: J. Chambers
